top_level.title: Charles Darwin born
top_level.body: Charles Darwin was born in Shrewsbury, Shropshire, the fifth of six children of Robert Waring Darwin, a doctor, and his wife Susannah, daughter of Josiah Wedgwood I.

top_level.title: Edinburgh University
top_level.body: In October 1825 Charles Darwin and his older brother, Erasmus, went to study medicine in Edinburgh

top_level.title: Cambridge University
top_level.body: Darwin goes to study at Christ's College, Cambridge

top_level.title: Beagle voyage begins
top_level.body: HMS Beagle sets sail from Plymouth with Darwin on board. What was supposed to be a two-year surveying voyage took five years to complete.

top_level.title: Leaves South America
top_level.body: The Beagle sets sail from Peru

top_level.title: The Beagle voyage ends
top_level.body: The Beagle anchors in Falmouth

top_level.title: London
top_level.body: Darwin moves to London

top_level.title: Glen Roy
top_level.body: Darwin makes a field trip to Glen Roy, Scotland, to observe the geological phenomenon of the 'parallel roads'.  He later described his theory of how the roads were created as 'one long gigantic blunder'

top_level.title: Marriage
top_level.body: Charles Darwin and Emma Wedgwood are married. They were first cousins. Darwin had proposed on 11 November 1838, describing it as the 'day of days!'.

top_level.title: Species theory outlined
top_level.body: Darwin writes a 32-page outline of his ideas on species change, known as 'the pencil sketch'

top_level.title: Moves to Down, Kent
top_level.body: The Darwins move to Down House, in the village of Down (later 'Downe'), Kent.  Darwin, who spent the rest of his life there, described it as a "good, very ugly house".

top_level.title: 'confessing a murder'
top_level.body: Darwin writes to Joseph Hooker with his ideas on species change; it is, he says, 'like confessing a murder'. Darwin and Hooker had only recently begun to correspond but the two men became close friends and Hooker remained Darwin's main sounding board.

top_level.title: Second species sketch
top_level.body: Darwin finishes an expanded sketch of his species theory, first drafted in 1842

top_level.title: Begins work on barnacles
top_level.body: Darwin begins an 8-year taxonomic study of barnacles

top_level.title: Father dies
top_level.body: Darwin's father, Robert Waring Darwin. dies in Shrewsbury

top_level.title: Mother dies
top_level.body: Darwin's mother, Susannah, died in Shrewsbury

top_level.title: Death of Annie Darwin
top_level.body: The Darwins' 10-year old daughter, Anne Elizabeth, dies in Malvern.  Charles is with her, but Emma, heavily pregnant, has to stay behind at Down.

top_level.title: Begins 'Natural Selection'
top_level.body: Darwin begins writing his 'big book', Natural Selection. The book was never finished, but later formed the basis for On the Origin of Species

top_level.title: Tenth child born
top_level.body: The Darwins' tenth and last child, Charles Waring Darwin, is born

top_level.title: Species theory made public
top_level.body: Articles by both Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace describing their independently derived theories of species change, are read at a meeting of the Linnean Society. Darwin was at home with his family following the death of his son, Charles Waring, on 28 June.  Wallace was on a field trip in the Malay archipelago.

top_level.title: Origin published
top_level.body: Darwin's most famous book, On the Origin of Species, is published and sells out immediately

top_level.title: American civil war
top_level.body: The American civil war begins

top_level.title: Amy Darwin dies
top_level.body: Darwin's daughter-in-law, Amy, dies four days after the birth of her son, Bernard.  He was the Darwins' first grandchild.

top_level.title: First of the barnacle books
top_level.body: After eight years of research, Darwin publishes  Living Cirripedia vol 1, the first of four volumes classifying living and fossil barnacles

top_level.title: Variation published
top_level.body: Darwin's two-volume work, Variation under domestication, is published.  It is so packed with data on breeds of all sorts of birds and animals that the text is published in two sizes of type: regular type for the main argument, and 'small print' for the supporting evidence.

top_level.title: Descent published
top_level.body: Darwin publishes Descent of Man and Selection in Relation to Sex, his first public statement on human evolution. All 2500 copies were sold in a week.

top_level.title: Expression published
top_level.body: Darwin publishes Expression of the emotions in man and animals, one of the first popular science books to be illustrated with photographs.  It was in such demand that his publisher thought they might need a police guard.

top_level.title: Death of Susannah Darwin
top_level.body: Darwin's mother, Susannah, died when he was eight years old. He said later he could remember 'hardly anything about her except her death-bed, her black velvet gown, and her curiously constructed work-table' (Autobiography).

top_level.title: Insectivorous Plants published
top_level.body: Darwin's book, Insectivorous plants, demonstrating that some plant species not only attract animal prey but can digest it, is published. Darwin predicted poor sales but following initial publication on 2 July, two further printings were needed in quick succession. "lo & behold" wrote Darwin's publisher, "we have sold some 1700 Copies!!!"

top_level.title: Darwin dies
top_level.body: Charles Darwin died at his home, Down House, in Kent.  He was buried a few days later, with full honours, in Westminster Abbey

1809.title: Charles Darwin born
1809.body: Charles Darwin was born in Shrewsbury, Shropshire, the fifth of six children of Robert Waring Darwin, a doctor, and his wife Susannah, daughter of Josiah Wedgwood I.

1822.title: Darwin’s brother Erasmus goes to Christ’s College, Cambridge

1825.title: Edinburgh University
1825.body: In October 1825 Charles Darwin and his older brother, Erasmus, went to study medicine in Edinburgh

1826.title: Erasmus moves to London
1826.body: Darwin's brother, Erasmus, leaves Edinburgh to go to Cambridge University

1828.title: Cambridge University
1828.body: Darwin goes to study at Christ's College, Cambridge

1831.title: Beagle voyage begins
1831.body: HMS Beagle sets sail from Plymouth with Darwin on board. What was supposed to be a two-year surveying voyage took five years to complete.

1833.title: Inland expeditions
1833.body: Darwin travels overland to Buenos Aires and Santa Fe

1834.title: Chile
1834.body: The Beagle arrives at the island of Chiloé, Chile

1834.title: The Andes
1834.body: Darwin goes on a geological expedition in the Andes

1836.title: Africa
1836.body: The Beagle arrives at the Cape of Good Hope

1837.title: Transmutation notes
1837.body: Darwin starts writing notes on 'transmutation of species'

1838.title: Glen Roy
1838.body: Darwin makes a field trip to Glen Roy, Scotland, to observe the geological phenomenon of the 'parallel roads'.  He later described his theory of how the roads were created as 'one long gigantic blunder'

1838.title: Engagement to Emma Wedgwood
1838.body: Darwin proposes to his cousin, Emma Wedgwood, and is accepted

1838.title: Zoology of the Beagle published
1838.body: The first part of The Zoology of the voyage of HMS Beagle is published. Darwin organised and superintended its publication, and wrote up the locations of the fossils, and the habitats and behaviour of the living species, he had collected.

1839.title: Marriage
1839.body: Charles Darwin and Emma Wedgwood are married. They were first cousins. Darwin had proposed on 11 November 1838, describing it as the 'day of days!'.

1839.title: William Darwin born
1839.body: The Darwins' first child, William Erasmus Darwin, is born.  His father immediately starts to record observations on his behaviour and development. Years later these are published in the journal Mind.

1839.title: Journal of Researches published
1839.body: Darwin's account of the Beagle voyage, based on his personal diaries, is published and is a great success. It appeared as the third volume of the Narrative of the surveying voyage of H.M.S. Adventure and Beagle, with the title Journal and remarks but was almost immediately republished and sold separately as Journal of researches into the geology and natural history of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle.

1842.title: Species theory outlined
1842.body: Darwin writes a 32-page outline of his ideas on species change, known as 'the pencil sketch'

1842.title: Moves to Down, Kent
1842.body: The Darwins move to Down House, in the village of Down (later 'Downe'), Kent.  Darwin, who spent the rest of his life there, described it as a "good, very ugly house".

1842.title: Mary Darwin
1842.body: The Darwins' second daughter and third child, Mary Darwin, is born; she dies on 16 October

1843.title: Meets Joseph Hooker
1843.body: Darwin begins a 40-year friendship with Joseph Dalton Hooker.  In November Hooker begins work on Darwin's Beagle plant specimens.

1844.title: 'confessing a murder'
1844.body: Darwin writes to Joseph Hooker with his ideas on species change; it is, he says, 'like confessing a murder'. Darwin and Hooker had only recently begun to correspond but the two men became close friends and Hooker remained Darwin's main sounding board.

1845.title: Second species sketch
1845.body: Darwin finishes an expanded sketch of his species theory, first drafted in 1842

1845.title: George Darwin born
1845.body: The Darwins' son George Howard Darwin born

1846.title: Begins work on barnacles
1846.body: Darwin begins an 8-year taxonomic study of barnacles

1848.title: Father dies
1848.body: Darwin's father, Robert Waring Darwin. dies in Shrewsbury

1817.title: Death of Susannah Darwin
1817.body: Darwin's mother, Susannah, died when he was eight years old. He said later he could remember 'hardly anything about her except her death-bed, her black velvet gown, and her curiously constructed work-table' (Autobiography).

1850.title: Leonard Darwin born
1850.body: The Darwins' eighth child and fourth son, Leonard, is born

1851.title: Death of Annie Darwin
1851.body: The Darwins' 10-year old daughter, Anne Elizabeth, dies in Malvern.  Charles is with her, but Emma, heavily pregnant, has to stay behind at Down.

1851.title: Horace Darwin born
1851.body: Darwin's son, and ninth child, Horace is born

1856.title: Begins 'Natural Selection'
1856.body: Darwin begins writing his 'big book', Natural Selection. The book was never finished, but later formed the basis for On the Origin of Species

1856.title: Tenth child born
1856.body: The Darwins' tenth and last child, Charles Waring Darwin, is born

1858.title: Letter from Wallace
1858.body: Alfred Russel Wallace, who was collecting natural history specimens in the Malay archipelago, sends Darwin an outline of his own theory of species change. Darwin was deeply shocked at how similar Wallace's ideas were to his own.

1858.title: Charles Waring Darwin dies
1858.body: The Darwins' baby son, Charles Waring, dies of scarlet fever

1858.title: Species theory made public
1858.body: Articles by both Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace describing their independently derived theories of species change, are read at a meeting of the Linnean Society. Darwin was at home with his family following the death of his son, Charles Waring, on 28 June.  Wallace was on a field trip in the Malay archipelago.

1859.title: Origin published
1859.body: Darwin's most famous book, On the Origin of Species, is published and sells out immediately

1860.title: British Association debate
1860.body: Origin is debated at a meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.  Samuel Wilberforce, Bishop of Oxford, spoke against it and was famously rebuked by Thomas Henry Huxley.

1861.title: Death of Henslow
1861.body: John Stevens Henslow, Darwin's Cambridge tutor, dies. It was Henslow who suggested Darwin for the Beagle voyage and the two remained friends to the end of Henslow's life.

1864.title: Copley medal
1864.body: Darwin is finally, and controversially, awarded the Copley medal by the Royal Society

1871.title: Henrietta Darwin marries
1871.body: The Darwins' daughter, Henrietta, marries Richard Buckley Litchfield

1871.title: Descent published
1871.body: Darwin publishes Descent of Man and Selection in Relation to Sex, his first public statement on human evolution. All 2500 copies were sold in a week.

1874.title: Francis Darwin marries
1874.body: The Darwins' son, Francis, marries Amy Ruck; Francis starts work as his father's assistant

1876.title: Grandson, Bernard Darwin born
1876.body: The Darwins' first grandchild, Bernard, is born, the son of Francis Darwin and his wife, Amy.

1876.title: Amy Darwin dies
1876.body: Darwin's daughter-in-law, Amy, dies four days after the birth of her son, Bernard.  He was the Darwins' first grandchild.

1852.title: First of the barnacle books
1852.body: After eight years of research, Darwin publishes  Living Cirripedia vol 1, the first of four volumes classifying living and fossil barnacles

1868.title: Variation published
1868.body: Darwin's two-volume work, Variation under domestication, is published.  It is so packed with data on breeds of all sorts of birds and animals that the text is published in two sizes of type: regular type for the main argument, and 'small print' for the supporting evidence.

1872.title: Expression published
1872.body: Darwin publishes Expression of the emotions in man and animals, one of the first popular science books to be illustrated with photographs.  It was in such demand that his publisher thought they might need a police guard.

1875.title: Insectivorous Plants published
1875.body: Darwin's book, Insectivorous plants, demonstrating that some plant species not only attract animal prey but can digest it, is published. Darwin predicted poor sales but following initial publication on 2 July, two further printings were needed in quick succession. "lo & behold" wrote Darwin's publisher, "we have sold some 1700 Copies!!!"

1882.title: Darwin dies
1882.body: Charles Darwin died at his home, Down House, in Kent.  He was buried a few days later, with full honours, in Westminster Abbey
